image.altText: An elderly Aboriginal man wearing a wide-brimmed hat

items.synopsis: The ABC spoke to a number of First Nations people in Sydney and the regions to hear what the Voice means to them.

title.children: At 101, Bigambul man Wes has seen 'so many promises' broken. Now he's voting on the Voice

image.altText: Male rescue workers working near the site of a badly damaged building.Trees in the background.

items.synopsis: Ukrainian officials say a Russian attack on a village in the north-east of the country has killed 51 people, including a child.

title.children: 'No military targets': Russian missile attack kills more than 50 civilians in one of the deadliest strikes in Ukraine war

image.altText: A man in a suit jacket sits down.

items.synopsis: Follow our live blog for the latest news in the lead-up to voting in the referendum on October 14.

title.children: Yes campaigner Thomas Mayo denounces threats against Lidia Thorpe

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Tavleen Singh Rapper Briggs's Yes concert, named 'Now and Forever' kicks off today in Shepparton, Victoria. The activist group A.B.Original released a song titled Yes, delivering an impassioned endorsement of a Yes vote in the referendum on an Indigenous Voice to Parliament. The track featuring Indigenous rapper Briggs, has gone off with over 4 million hits already. "I think that it speaks to that generation," says Briggs on the popularity of the song. "I reckon this is how people are talking in the pubs and in the lounge rooms." An impressive line-up of artists including Paul Kelly, Jimmy Barnes and Hilltop Hoods will be performing at Shepparton today in to inform more people about the Voice Referendum. Organised by Briggs, the day-long Yes concert is aimed at undecided voters. "Over the last few weeks, I was just wanting to put more positive stuff into the sphere, because it was like, so much vitriol and so negative." Briggs tells ABC News Breakfast. "And I think that the best way that we can show people what a Yes might look like is by putting a show together with artists that share the same kind of vision for unity and solidarity." Victoria has been inundated with heavy rains this week but the rapper and activist is hopeful the rain will hold off today.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rapper Briggs's Yes concert, named 'Now and Forever' kicks off today

props.alt: A man wears a cap siting down.

children.content: Rapper Briggs has organised the concert.
(ABC News)
Reporting by Tavleen Singh
Rapper Briggs's
Yes concert, named 'Now and Forever' kicks off today in
Shepparton, Victoria.
The activist group A.B.Original released a song titled Yes, delivering an impassioned endorsement of a Yes vote in the referendum on an
Indigenous Voice to Parliament
The track featuring Indigenous rapper Briggs, has gone off with over 4 million hits already.
"I think that it speaks to that generation," says Briggs on the popularity of the song.
"I reckon this is how people are talking in the pubs and in the lounge rooms."
An impressive line-up of artists including
Paul Kelly
Jimmy Barnes
and
Hilltop Hoods
will be performing at Shepparton today in to inform more people about the Voice Referendum.
Organised by Briggs, the day-long Yes concert is aimed at undecided voters.
"Over the last few weeks, I was just wanting to put more positive stuff into the sphere, because it was like, so much vitriol and so negative." Briggs tells
ABC News Breakfast
"And I think that the best way that we can show people what a Yes might look like is by putting a show together with artists that share the same kind of vision for unity and solidarity."
Victoria has been inundated with heavy rains this week but the rapper and activist is hopeful the rain will hold off today.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Today former chief justice of Australia Robert French will be speaking at the National Press Club in Canberra. His address is titled The Voice – Filling a Long Constitutional Silence. He will be speaking from 12:30pm AEDT and we will be bringing it to you live.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Coming up today: Robert French speaking at National Press Club

children.content: Today former chief justice of Australia
Robert French
will be speaking at the National Press Club in Canberra.
His address is titled
The Voice – Filling a Long Constitutional Silence.
He will be speaking from 12:30pm AEDT and we will be bringing it to you live.

props.alt: Robert French stands smiling in front of a book shel

children.content: Robert French.
(ABC News: Georgia Hitch)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Tavleen Singh Independent senator Lidia Thorpe was tagged in a video of a Neo-Nazi burning an Aboriginal flag while doing a Nazi salute. The Indigenous senator says the police failed to protect her and ministers from across the board including Prime Minister Anthony Albanese have condemned the abuse directed at Ms Thorpe. "There is a question for the no campaign to answer about these sorts of extremists on the no side," says Yes vote advocate Thomas Mayo. He says it is an issue to be answered but people should not forget what the referendum is about. "We can't be distracted. That sort of thing needs to be dealt with but this referendum is ultimately at the end of the day just about recognising Indigenous people by giving us a say," he said speaking on ABC News Breakfast. "It is horrible to see that behaviour and those threats and it is something that we don't want to see in Australian politics." With just over a week left for the Voice to Parliament referendum vote, both sides are making the final push to secure more votes. "We have just got to keep our focus on improving this country, building a better future for our children, for all Australians by saying yes," he says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'It is horrible': Yes campaigner Thomas Mayo on threats directed at Lidia Thorpe

props.alt: A bald man sits on a couch wearing a blazer.

children.content: Thomas Mayo says the threats against Lidia Thorpe were horrible.
(ABC News)
Reporting by Tavleen Singh
Independent senator
Lidia Thorpe
was tagged in a video of a Neo-Nazi burning an Aboriginal flag while doing a Nazi salute.
The Indigenous senator says the police failed to protect her and ministers from across the board including
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese
have condemned the abuse directed at Ms Thorpe.
"There is a question for the no campaign to answer about these sorts of extremists on the no side," says Yes vote advocate
Thomas Mayo.
He says it is an issue to be answered but people should not forget what the referendum is about.

"We can't be distracted. That sort of thing needs to be dealt with but this referendum is ultimately at the end of the day just about recognising Indigenous people by giving us a say," he said speaking on
ABC News Breakfast
"It is horrible to see that behaviour and those threats and it is something that we don't want to see in Australian politics."
With just over a week left for the
Voice to Parliament
referendum vote, both sides are making the final push to secure more votes.
"We have just got to keep our focus on improving this country, building a better future for our children, for all Australians by saying yes," he says.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Flooding in Victoria is likely to cause a temporary shortage of vegetables and fruit. Farmers have seen their crops wiped out and infrastructure wash away, costing them millions. You can continue reading this story:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Flood damage in Victoria to cause fruit and veggie supply shortage

Farmers have seen their crops wiped out and infrastructure wash away, costing them millions.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Fair Work Ombudsman has vowed to use yet-to-be-legislated criminal penalties against employers who deliberately underpay or rip off their workers. Anna Booth, who began as the fair work cop last month, says the risk of jail time would be a major deterrent to dodgy bosses. Read more on this story by senior business correspondent Peter Ryan:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Employers who underpay workers could face jail time

featuredLink.title: New Fair Work Ombudsman vows to use criminal penalties to clamp down on wage theft

children.content: The Fair Work Ombudsman has vowed to use yet-to-be-legislated criminal penalties against employers who deliberately underpay or rip off their workers.
Anna Booth, who began as the fair work cop last month, says the risk of jail time would be a major deterrent to dodgy bosses.
Read more on this story by senior business correspondent Peter Ryan:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning. I'm Emily Stewart and I'll be keeping you up-to-date with all today's business and finance news. It's expected Aussie shares may open ever so slightly higher this morning after slight falls on Wall Street overnight. Investors have been grappling with US unemployment figures, which reveal the labour market is still tight. Oil prices continue to slide as demand remains uncertain. Here at home, we'll be keeping an eye on the Reserve Bank. It releases its half-yearly financial stability review this morning, which may give us an indication of how households are faring with higher interest rates. Let's get through to the weekend together!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Happy Friday!

children.content: Good morning.
I'm Emily Stewart and I'll be keeping you up-to-date with all today's business and finance news.
It's expected Aussie shares may open ever so slightly higher this morning after slight falls on Wall Street overnight.
Investors have been grappling with US unemployment figures, which reveal the labour market is still tight.
Oil prices continue to slide as demand remains uncertain.
Here at home, we'll be keeping an eye on the Reserve Bank.
It releases its half-yearly financial stability review this morning, which may give us an indication of how households are faring with higher interest rates.
Let's get through to the weekend together!

items.synopsis: Syria's Defence Ministry says "terrorist" groups used drones to carry out the deadly attack that killed civilians and military personnel attending a graduate ceremony at the military academy in the central province of Homs.

title.children: At least 100 killed in drone attack on Syrian military academy

title.children: 'Vicious' kangaroo attack leaves 74yo man half-clothed and bleeding

title.children: Aussies claim T20 series victory over Windies despite Matthews's heroics
